title: Questions asked in Lecture 2
text:
The following points were discussed in the lecture.

An ecosystem is a community of living organisms (plants, animals, and microorganisms) interacting with their physical environment (soil, water, and air).
Forest is a type of landscape ecosystem.







What do we have two terms landscape-ecosystem and ecosystem?



In my opinion, both ecosystem and landscape ecosystem are essentially the same. The term ecosystem is very general. However, from landscape ecosystem we want to emphasis that we are interested in studying the ecosystem which have finite volume such as forest. So such ecosystem are located on the specific parts of the earth. They have their own environment, and in this environment their can be so population of many types of species.



I think to study the forest ecosystem, the first question that we should ask is where is that forest located on the earth?
Is it is a tropical forest, or temperate forest, or boreal forest?
Then we decide our are of interest by fixing the spatial scale of the forest ecosystem. This will fix the volume of the forest in the horizontal direction. Imagine a box which contains a part of very large forest.
After fixing the volume of the forest, we see what types of living organisms are present in that volume.
Then we see what is the geography in that volume, For example, what is the soil type, what is the water type, what is the air type, what is the temperature, what is the humidity, what is the light intensity, etc. We also check the topography.
In summary, in landscape ecosystem, and forest ecosystem, the landscape comes first, and then we study the components of that landscape. Whereas in general, many people are interested in studying an organism or species, or population. But if use such approach for a forest we have so many species and their ecosystem. Finding how these ecosystem (infinitely many) interacts with each other will be a challenging task if not impossible task.




To understand the different layers of a forest ecosystem, we need to follow the following steps.

The forest ecosystem occupy a finite volume (small or larger) on the earth’s surface.
The conditions, such as temperature, humidity, light, soil type, nutrients, rainfall (amount and frequency) will change across the earth surface. In this way, different types of plants (species) will grow at different location on the earth. Even if we focus on same species, their growth will be different at different location. This is because the conditions are different at different locations. This gives a horizontal structure to forest. All it means that the growth, species of plants and trees changes as the location changes.
Now let us focus on the vertical structure of a forest. The vertical structure of the forest is divided in the terms of layers. For example, our body has differnt layers:

Leg area: This is the area below the hip
Hip area: This is the area around the hip
Stomach area: This is the area around the stomach
Head area: This is the area around the head


Similarly, in the forest at given location on the earth, we have different layers in the vertical direction. Now why in the vertical direction? Because at given location the trees are growing in the vertical direction (both up and down (roots)).
Now, Let us focus on a SINGLE tree at a given location. What type of layers do we observe? 1. Root area (this is like leg area) below the ground 2. Trunk area (this is like hip and stomach area) above the ground 3. Crown area: Branch area (this is like head area) above the ground. 4. Canopy area: This is the area above the crown area. This is the area where the leaves are present.
Now let us combine many trees at a given location. Let say we planted them together. Over the time they will grow at the different rate. Some trees will be taller and thicker. Some trees will be shorter. This the first generation of tree. They have same age, but their characteristics are different. After some years lets plant another generation of trees. Now in the forest we will have younger and older trees. Every individual tree has vertical structure.
The combination of these trees is what make the forest. So the forest also have several vertical layers. These layers were discussed in the lecture.



One student found it difficult to understand the tropical ecosystem.

The tropical ecosystem is a type of forest ecosystem.
It is a forest ecosystem that is located in the tropics.
The tropics are the regions of the earth that are located between the Tropic of Cancer (23 degree North) and the Tropic of Capricorn (23 degree South).
These regions are characterized by warm temperatures and high levels of rainfall. In general, as the latitude increases, the temperature decreases. Arctic and Antartica both have largest latitude in North and Sourth, respectively. They are also the cold region of the earth.
Find the latitude of you location. For example, Kyoto’s latitude is 35.0116° N. So it is not in the tropics. The latitude of Mumbai, India is 19.0760° N. So it is in the tropics.
You can learn about the latitude of earth from this YouTube Video
The tropical ecosystem is home to a wide variety of plant and animal species, many of which are not found in other types of ecosystems.
The tropical ecosystem is also characterized by its high levels of biodiversity, which means that it has a large number of different species living in it.
I also recommend students to see this YouTube Video to understand the tropical ecosystem.





The population is a group of individuals of the same species that live in the same area at the same time.
A population is defined as a group of individuals of the same species living and interbreeding within a given area.
Members of a population often rely on the same resources, are subject to similar environmental constraints, and depend on the availability of other members to persist over time.
We study a population by examining how individuals in that population interact with each other and how the population as a whole interacts with its environment.
As a tool for objectively studying populations, population ecologists rely on a series of statistical measures, known as demographic parameters, to describe that population.
The field of science interested in collecting and analyzing these numbers is termed population demographics, also known as demography.

I strongly recommend students to watch the following YouTube Video to understand the concept of population.

Population dynamics is an very intriguing subject. I can recommend the following article to understand the concept of population in an ecosystem.

https://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/introduction-to-population-demographics-83032908/

The process that occur in cells and organs of individual plants affect the growth and form of the whole plant.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Forest stories come from tree (mainly)
The stories of forests assemble from the stories of the life cycles of individual trees, along with the stories of understory vegetation, animals, and microbes.

Forest

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Forest tree variation

A forest tree, or any other organism, cannot exist independently of its environment in which it lives.
Both genetic and environmental factors influence the growth and form of trees.








Adaptedness


Adaptedness is the ability of organisms to live and reproduce in a given range of environments.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Adaptedness in a forest ecosystem

Example: The thick bark of the cork oak (Quercus suber), which is a clear adaptation to frequent forest fires in Mediterranean-type environments.


The cork oak develops an exceptionally thick, spongy bark composed primarily of suberin, a hydrophobic, fire-resistant substance. This thick bark serves as an insulating layer, protecting the tree’s cambium and inner tissues from the intense heat of wildfires. The cork oak’s ability to regenerate its bark after fire damage is a key factor in its survival in fire-prone environments.










Cork characteristics Molina et al. (2018)







Fire in Cork oak tree

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Genotype and Phenotype







Genotype


Genotype is the genetic constitution of an organism, which is determined by the alleles inherited from its parents.





We can never see a genotype because from the moment of fertilization the genotype is influenced by the plant’s environment; its internal environment of cells and biochemical reactions and its external environment of light, temperature, and moisure.








Phenotype


Phenotype is the observable characteristics of an organism, which are influenced by both genetic and environmental factors.




\[
P = G + E + GE
\]

P = phenotype, G = genotype, E = environment, GE = genotype-environment interaction

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Components of phenotypic variation

To what degree a phenotypic trait is influenced by genetic factors (G) and environmental factors (E)
For example, consider a dominant tree exhibiting excellent growth in a forest plantation and an adjacent dying tree of the same species.
In this case, we know that dominant tree has a superior phenotype, but we do not know if the tree is genetically superior or if it is simply growing in a more favorable environment. Basically,

To what degree is its genotype resonsible
Too what degree does a favorable microenvironment or the random factor of better handling in the nursery acccount for its superior growth?

The important point is the relative degree of genetic and nongenetic influence on a given character.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Plasticity of the Phenotype
A given genotype may assume one set of characters (exhibit one phenotype) in one environment and exhibit a different phenotype in another environment.







Plasticity of the Phenotype


It is the degree to which a character of a given genotype can be modified by environmental factors.










An example of plasticity of adaptive significance is the rooting habit of individual trees such as Norway spruce, white spruce, and balsam fir. Roots develop either shallow or deep, depending on the soil environment, for example, shallow in a poorly-drained swamp versus deeply in a sandy loam upland soil.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Source of variation

As we have seen, the variation among phenotypes is attributed partially to genetic differences and partially to environmental differences.
The major sources of genetic variation are mutations and recombination.








Mutations


Mutations are changes in the DNA sequence of an organism’s genome, which can lead to new traits or characteristics.











Recombination


Recombination occurs during sexual reproduction when genetic material from two parents is combined to produce offspring with a unique combination of traits.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Source of variation

Altough mutations are the ultimate source of genetic variation, recombination is the most important source of genetic variation in sexually reproducing organisms.








Gene flow


The exchange of genes between different populations is called gene flow, and it can also contribute to genetic variation within a population.





For example, migrants in the form of pollen and seeds bring to a population new genetic material from other populations.
When the population involved are significantly different genetically, the introduction of new genes can have a significant impact on the genetic variation of the population. This is termed as hybridization.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Seeds of tree







Definition


A seed is a plant structure containing an embryo and stored nutrients in a protective coat called a testa.







In seed plants (spermatophytes), seed formation is the part of the process of reproduction.
Other plants such as ferns, mosses and liverworts, do not have seeds and use water-dependent means to propagate themselves.
The size of seeds varies significantly.





Variety of seeds Source: Alexander Klepnev Wikimedia

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Seeds of tree






Seedlings that develop from large seeds (such as walnuts and acorns) have a great advantage over seedlings endowed with very, very tiny seeds (such as cottonwoods and willows).












Wallnut seeds, 1







Acorn of the willow oak 2







Stone pine 3







Cottonwood seeds 4

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Big vs Small seeds



Successful establishment of tiny‐seed species tends to happen only under ideal conditions of high light, high water, and high nutrient supply.
For example, cottonwood seeds are so small that it takes about 5000 to add up to a single gram of mass! Successful germinants occur on recent flood deposits that have the requisite light, water and nutrients. Recent flood deposits dry out as the water table recedes, and first‐year growth and survival depend on whether seedling roots can descend into the soil quickly enough to tap receding water and nutrient supplies.





source: Adair and Binkley (2002)
Big seeds contain large supplies of carbohydrates in it which might be beneficial for new germinants. So it might seem that all tree species should produce large seeds.
New germinants of pines benefit from seeds that are much larger than cottonwoods seeds (25 seeds per gram), and oak and walnut germinants have far larger seeds than pines (5–10 g for each seed).
However, big seeds fall only in the vicinity near the mother tree, which is a difficult place for successful regeneration.
Large seeds may be eaten by birds and mammals, with chance of being destroyed (by digestion) or dispersed to favorable sites.
Tiny seeds allow for dispersion by wind with the potential that some seeds will land in favorable sites.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
section: Flow of energy in a tree
text:
Flow of energy in a tree

A tree uses photosynthesis to convert the solar energy into chemical energy which is stored inside the tree.




Photosynthesis source Wikimedia



The chemical energy is stored inside the tree in the organic compounds, which is used for various physiological processes of plants, animals, and microbes.
Through photosynthesis plant convert carbon dioxide and water into carbohydrates, which are then used to build the tree’s structure and fuel its growth.




The growth of the tree source YouTube



In this way, the biological processes of forest ecology are driven by chemical energy.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Chemical reactions and energy

Chemical reactions can be classfied into two categories:

Exothermic reactions: release energy (e.g., combustion of wood)
Endothermic reactions: absorb energy (e.g., photosynthesis)

In Exothermic reactions, the energy of the products is lower than that of the reactants, and the difference in energy is released as heat. Respiration in plants is an exothermic reaction.
In Endothermic reactions, the energy of the products is higher than that of the reactants, and the difference in energy is absorbed as heat. Photosynthesis in plants is an endothermic reaction.




Chemical reactions can be viewed as the flow of energy and electrons. In exothermic reactions electron moves to lower energy products while in endothermic reactions electrons move to higher energy compounds.




The electrons cannot be created or destroyed, but they can be transferred from one atom to another. So the flow of electrons can only occur from a source connected to a sink.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Redox reactions

The electron flow is called reduction-oxidation (redox) reaction.




A redox reaction, short for reduction–oxidation reaction, is a type of chemical reaction that involves the transfer of electrons between two substances



\[
Zn(s)+Cu^{2+}(aq)\rightarrow Zn^{2+}(aq)+Cu(s)
\]
In the above reaction, \(Zn(s) \rightarrow Zn^{+2} + 2e\) is giving up the electron, whereas \(Cu^{+2} + 2e \rightarrow Cu\) is accepting the electrons.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Redox reaction

A redox reaction is composed of two processes occuring at the same time:








Oxidation


Oxidation: The process in which a substance is losing the electrons. This process increases the oxidation state of the substance.
\[
Zn \rightarrow Zn^{+2} + 2e
\]











Reduction


Reduction: The process in which a substance is gaining the electrons. This process decreases the oxidation state of the substance.
\[
Cu^{+2} + 2e \rightarrow Cu
\]

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Redox reactions







Reducing agent


The substance that loses electrons is called the reducing agent, because it will promote the reduction of other substance. In \(Zn(s)+Cu^{2+}(aq)\rightarrow Zn^{2+}(aq)+Cu(s)\), Zn is acting as the reducing agent.











Oxidizing agent


The substance that gains electron is called the oxidizing agent, because it will promote the oxidation of other substance. In \(Zn(s)+Cu^{2+}(aq)\rightarrow Zn^{2+}(aq)+Cu(s)\), Cu is acting as the oxidizing agent.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Redox reactions in forests: Respiration

Respiration in plants is an exothermic reaction. The chemical energy stored inside the organic molecules such as carbohydrates like glucose (\(C_{6}H_{12}O_{6}\)) is released by breaking down of molecules.
The primary form of respiration in plants is aerobic respiration (using oxygen), although anaerobic respiration can occur under low-oxygen conditions.








aerobic respiration


The overall chemical reaction for aerobic respiration in plants is:
\[
C_{6}H_{12}O_{6}+6O_{2}\rightarrow 6CO_{2}+6H_{2}O+Energy (ATP)
\]

In the above reaction oxygen is taking the electron, hence it is an oxidizing agent. Sugar is oxidizing into \(CO_{2}\) and \(H_{2}O\).
Organic molecules store energy in chemical bonds, and the energy is released as electrons flow from organic molecules to oxygen.
This reaction forms low energy products water and carbon dioxide.
The energy produced is utilized by plants to perform various vital functions, including growth, reproduction, and defense against pathogens.






The aerobic respiration mainly occur in cytoplasm and mitocondria. It contains three major steps.








Stage
Location (in cell)
Main Process




1. Glycolysis
Cytoplasm
Glucose split into two molecules of pyruvate; small ATP yield


2. Krebs Cycle (Citric Acid Cycle)
Mitochondrial matrix
Pyruvate broken down; CO₂ released; electron carriers formed


3. Electron Transport Chain (ETC)
Inner mitochondrial membrane
Electrons transferred; large amount of ATP generated; O₂ consumed

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Redox reactions in forests: Photosynthesis







Photosynthesis


Photosynthesis is a biochemical reaction that occurs in the chloroplasts of plant cells. During photosynthesis, plants capture light energy from the sun and convert it into chemical energy stored in glucose and other organic molecules.
\[
ATP + \text{H}_{2}O + \text{CO}_{2} \rightarrow \text{Sugar} + \text{O}_{2}
\]
The products of photosynthesis contain only carbon, oxygen and hydrogen. The mass of these three elements accounts for more than 90% of the dry mass of trees and other plants.









flowchart LR
  A[Sunlight] --> C{Photosynthesis, Chlorophyll}
  D[Carbon dioxide 6CO2] --> C
  W[Water 6H20] --> C
  C --> B[Sugar C6H12O6 + Oxygen 6O2]

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Photosynthesis







Where does most of the material in this piece of wood come from?



Molecules dissolved in water
Large soil molecules (humus)
Inorganic molecules from the soil
Small molecules in the air

It is surprising that air could provide the materials that make very solid pieces of wood. The carbon that comprises about half the mass of organic molecules (such as wood) does come from carbon dioxide molecules floating around in the air. (For an excellent documentary about how students learn but fail to understand, see: the documentary.)

Plant leaf

A leaf is a principal appendage of the stem of a vascular plant.
Leaves are part of the shoot system.


Leaves showing various morphologies (clockwise from upper left): tripartite lobation, elliptic with serrulate margin, palmate venation, acuminate odd-pinnate (center), pinnatisect, lobed, elliptic with entire margin

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text: Plant leaf structure

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Plant leaf structure (medium scale features)

Medium-scale features: Leaves are normally extensively vascularized and typically have networks of vascular bundles containing xylem, which supplies water for photosynthesis, and phloem, which transports the sugars produced by photosynthesis. Many leaves are covered in trichomes (small hairs) which have diverse structures and functions.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Plant leaf structure (small scale features)

Small-scale features: (a) The epidermis, which covers the upper and lower surfaces, (b) The mesophyll tissue, which consists of photosynthetic cells rich in chloroplasts. (also called chlorenchyma), (c) The arrangement of veins (the vascular tissue)

text:
Colors of leaves







Pigments


Pigments are organic compounds that absorb light at specific wavelengths and reflect or transmit light at other wavelengths. The color of a pigment is determined by the wavelengths of light it absorbs and reflects.











Why are leaves green?


The sunlight has a spectrum of colors that combine to make white light, and leaves absorb red, yellow, and blue light with green light reflecting from the leaves.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Colors of leaves







Sunlight



The sunlight has a spectrum of colors that combine to make white light.
Actually, light doesn’t really come in colors.
Light (and other electromagnetic radiation) has wavelengths (or the inverse, frequencies) of oscillations.
Some chemicals effectively absorb only certain wavelengths, and that’s the case for receptors in our eyes.
We have receptors that are activated strongly by light with wavelengths near 440, 540, and 580 nm.
The electrical signals sent from our eyes are interpreted as colors in our brains, with millions of variations created by combining the intensities sensed in these bands of wavelengths.
The wavelengths themselves possess no property of color. Without eyes, the world has no color.




Visible light spectrum

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Colors of leaves

The green leaves actually absorb more than 80% of the green light from sunlight, reflecting only 10–15% of the green light.


The apparent color of leaves changes in the autumn as changing chemistry within the leaves reduces the absorption of some wavelengths, leading to higher reflectance. Yellow leaves still absorb green and blue wavelengths, and brown leaves absorb most wavelengths.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Chlorophyll

Molecules of chlorophyll do not absorb much of the green light
Our eyes interpret leaves as being green because green leaves absorb about 95% of the other visible wavelengths, but a bit less of the green light, so our eyes perceive more photons with a green wavelength than any others.










Seen through a microscope, chlorophyll is concentrated within organisms in structures called chloroplasts; shown here grouped inside plant cells







Molecular structure of chlorophyll d. Note that it contains Mg ion.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Carotenoids

These pigments are responsible for the yellow, orange, and red colors of many fruits and vegetables.
Carotenoids give the color to carrots, pumpkins, corn, and tomatoes.










Apricots, rich in carotenoids







Yellow and orange leaf colors in autumn are due to carotenoids, which are visible after chlorophyll degrades for the season.







The orange ring surrounding Grand Prismatic Spring is due to carotenoids produced by cyanobacteria and other bacteria.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Anthocyanins

Anthocyanins are pigments that can appear red, purple, or blue depending on the pH.
They are produced in the leaves of some plants in response to stress, such as high light intensity or low temperatures.










Purple cauliflower contains anthocyanins







Anthocyanins give these pansies their dark purple pigmentation







Superposition of spectra of chlorophyll a and b with oenin (malvidin 3O glucoside), a typical anthocyanin, showing that, while chlorophylls absorb in the blue and yellow/red parts of the visible spectrum, oenin absorbs mainly in the green part of the spectrum, where chlorophylls don’t absorb at all.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Photosynthesis

The growth of forests relates in part to the supply of water, because the uptake of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere can be accomplished only by exposing the moist interiors of leaves to the dry air.
For each CO2 molecule that diffuses from dry air into the moist interior of a leaf, something like 200–500 molecules of water escape into the atmosphere.





When water supplies are low, trees close the pores (stoma = mouth, stomata or stomates for plural) on leaves, minimizing water loss and unfortunately preventing uptake of CO2.










Stomata in tomato plant







Tomato stoma observed through immersion oil

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Photosynthesis

Plants transpire water at high rates when the supply of water is abundant, and when the atmosphere is not too dry


Rates of transpiration from leaves depends on the density and openness of leaf stomata (pores). Stomatal opening is indexed as stomatal conductance (how many molecules could slip through the stomata present on 1 m2 of total leaf area), and stomatal openings shrink as the air becomes drier. White pine needles and red oak leaves both have stomata that are sensitive to vapor pressure deficits, but the pine needles sustain more open stomata at all humidities (left). The amount of water lost from a leaf depends on stomatal conductance, the water status of the leaf (water potential, Figure 4.3), and the dryness of the air (right). With very dry air, the loss of water can go up even as stomata close down. The pine leaves transpire much more water at any given level of vapor pressure deficit than the oak leaves.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Photosynthesis



The story of potentials also explains how water moves against gravity, ascending tens of meters (or even one hundred of meters) upward in trees against the pull of gravity
Dry air has a tremendously negative potential compared to the insides of leaves, so water is sucked from leaves into the air.
The potential of water inside leaves is lower than in twigs, so the evaporated water is replaced in the leaf with water sucked from the twigs.
The twig’s water potential is lower than the stem, and the stem is lower than the root, and the root is lower than the water potential of the soil.





Water flows “down” gradients of potential, from high potentials in soils (which are high, even though the sign on the value is negative) to lower potentials in trees (more negative values)

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Photosynthesis



This chain of potentials moves water from the soil to the atmosphere, by virtue of the very strong ability of water molecules to stick to surfaces and to each other.
The potentials in soils and plants are typically negative, which means the potential is lower than in a free‐standing puddle of water on the soil surface (at a potential of 0 MPa).
Going from a higher potential to a lower potential means that water will flow down the potential gradient from −0.2 MPa in soils, to −1 or −2 MPa in trees, to −60 MPa (or lower) in dry air.





Water flows “down” gradients of potential, from high potentials in soils (which are high, even though the sign on the value is negative) to lower potentials in trees (more negative values)

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Growth and Photosynthesis



Plant growth depends on photosynthesis, but not necessarily on the recent photosynthesis.










Growth of plant


Growth refers to the irreversible increase in size, mass, and volume of a tree, involving both cell division (mitosis) and cell enlargement, and ultimately the formation of new tissues (e.g., roots, leaves, stems, xylem, phloem).











Respiration


Respiration in trees refers to a metabolic process in which organic compounds (mainly glucose) are broken down to release energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This process occurs in all living cells of the tree (leaves, stems, roots).
\(C6H12O6+6O2 \rightarrow 6CO2+6H2O+energy (ATP)\)





Sugar is the immediate product of photosynthesis, and sugars may be used quickly for respiration needs to maintain leaf cells.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Growth and Photosynthesis

Most sugars are converted to starches for short-term storage during the day, and starches are converted back to soluble sugars at night for transport through the plant.
In general, the timing of photosynthesis and growth is the same when the climate conditions are favorable.
These two processes, however, are not strongly coupled. Because plants have vast storage pools of carbohydrates, that are used over long periods of time to support thye growth of new cells and tissues.
The term (NSC) is used to describe these storage pools. They can add up to about 10% of the mass of plants.
Most of the C used in leaves and twigs is young, coming from recent photosynthesis. But the C in roots and woody tissues is older, coming from photosynthesis that occurred weeks or months earlier. Some pools of carbohydrates in roots are several years old, or even decades old Hartmann and Trumbore (2016).

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Growth and Photosynthesis



Plants use stored carbohydrates and nutrients to grow new leaves. It takes leaves about a week or two of photosynthesis to recover the cost of growing them, and then leaves support the plant.




The cost of sustaining leaves can be higher than the gains through photosynthesis if a leaf is too shaded.
The capture of light by leaves depends strongly on the amount of leaf area for a tree or forest, along with the orientation of leaves to the sun.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Leaf morphology






Leaf morphology is a result of the interaction between genetic and environmental factors.




No single design of a leaf would be optimal for photosynthesis in all situations
Therefore, leaf shapes range from cylindrical needles of some conifers to broad, thin leaves on many broadleaved tree species.
It is common to find a range of leaf shapes within the crowns of a single trees and canopies of a forest.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Leaf morphology study 1

The structure of leaves in the canopy of a rain forest in Costa Rica showed a clear pattern between the light environment of leaves and the how much mass was necessary to form 1 m2 of leaves (left). Leaves receiving full sun had a mass of about 120 g/m2, whereas leaves receiving 10% of full sunlight had a mass of about 90 g/m2. The correlation between leaf thickness and light does not mean that the light environment is the key factor determining leaf thickness. Indeed, the variation in leaf thickness related much better to simply how high leaves were off the ground (right, with observations from 45 profiles grouped into 7 height classes source: Cavaleri et al. (2010)

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Leaf morphology study 2

Left: Eucalyptus plantations in Hawaii also show a clear pattern between leaf mass and area as trees get taller with age, even though the light environment at the tops of the crowns remains the same Coble et al. (2014), Right: Needles on tall redwood trees in California also fit the pattern of increasing leaf mass area with height above the ground. Height above the ground influences leaf water potentials (right), both before dawn (after the tree’s water content has recovered overnight) and at mid‐day, leading to very large changes in needle morphology with height Koch et al. (2004)

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Leaf morphology study 3

The photosynthetic capacity of needles (with full sunlight) in a Norway spruce trees in Estonia declined with increasing height above the ground, because of interacting effects of structural differences (resulting in part from differences in water potential) and ecophysiological functioning Räim et al. (2012)
The ability of leaves to carry out photosynthesis is strongly affected by the influence of height on leaf structures and ecophysiological function.

Of course the amount of sunlight intercepted by a leaf may be lower in the lower canopy, so actual rates of photosynthesis would depend on both light supply and the photosynthetic capacity of leaves.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
section: Take home Question: Why is Understory of a Forest a Tough Place for Small Trees to Thrive?
text:
Take home Question: Why is Understory of a Forest a Tough Place for Small Trees to Thrive?
Hints:



Trees need sunlight and nutrients for photosynthesis, and the light is usually dim under the canopies of large trees.






The light passing through the canopy of a forest may amount to only 5% or less of the light that strikes the top of the canopy.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Root system

Primary and secondary roots in a cotton plant






Definition


In vascular plants, the roots are the organs of a plant that are modified to provide anchorage for the plant and take in water and nutrients into the plant body, which allows plants to grow taller and faster

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Functions of roots system

anchoring the plant to the ground (by whole root system)
absorbing water and nutrients from the soil (mainly by fine none woody roots smaller than 1 mm in diameter)
storing carbohydrates and other nutrients (mainly by larger woody roots)
transporting water and nutrients to the rest of the plant








Root system


The root system is characterized by a framework of relatively large, woody, long-lived roots (coarse roots) and a network of small, non-woody, short-lived roots (fine roots).

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
section: Large trees depend on large roots
text:
Large trees depend on large roots



The large roots of trees (called coarse roots) typically account for about 20% of the total mass of the trees.
When strong winds blow, the crowns of trees act as sails that intercept the force of the wind and transfer it to the stems
Trees can only transfer that force down the stem and into the ground.
In this way, well‐rooted trees can withstand very high winds, though severe storms can break or topple even strong trees.





This onyina (or kapok) tree in Ghana has large buttresses which dissipate the wind force that might topple an unbuttressed tree.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
section: Network of fine roots permeate soils
text:
Network of fine roots permeate soils

On an annual basis, the percentage increase in the size of a tree is usually not very large, ranging from less than 1% in large old trees to perhaps 20% (or even more) in the fast‐growing smaller trees.
If the mass of coarse roots needed to support a tree would be a constant 20%, then only small‐to‐moderate increases would be needed each year, with the growth of coarse roots each year accounting for a small part of the total production of a tree.
However, about 30% to 50% of the total photosynthates produced by trees flows to the belowground system, not for the formation of new coarse roots, but for the production and maintenance of small (fine) roots and their mycorrhizal symbionts. This will be discussed in next lectures.
The mass of fine roots may amount to 5–10% of the mass of a tree, but the fine roots typically live for one or a few years and so the cost of replacement accounts for a substantial proportion of a tree’s production.
Kucbel, Jaloviar, and Špišák (2011)
Christina et al. (2011)
Roots in desert trees Kirschner, Xiao, and Blilou (2021)

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Root system
There are two main types of root systems:

Taproot system: A single, thick primary root (the taproot) that grows deep into the soil, with smaller secondary roots branching off from it. This type of root system is common in dicotyledonous plants (e.g., carrots, dandelions).
Fibrous root system: A network of thin, branching roots that spread out horizontally near the soil surface. This type of root system is common in monocotyledonous plants (e.g., grasses, wheat).










Taproot system







Fibrous root system

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Morphology of roots


Modification of root systems of forest trees by site. (a) and (b) Taproots with reduced upper laterals: patterns found in coarse sandy soils underlain by fine-­textured substrata. (c) Taproot with long tassels, a structure induced by extended capillary fringe. (d) Superficial laterals and deep network of fibrous roots outlining an interlayer of porous materials. (e) Flattened heart-­root formed in lacustrine clay over a sand bed. (f) Plate-shaped root developed in a soil with a reasonably deep groundwater table. (g) Plate-­ shaped root formed in organic soils with shallow groundwater table. (h) Bimorphic system of platelike crown and taproot, found in leached soils with a surface rich in organic matter. (i) Flat root of angiosperms in strongly leached soils with raw humus at surface and hardpan below. (j) Two parallel plate roots connected by vertical sinkers in a hardpan spodosol. (k) Pneumatophores of mangrove trees in tidal lands.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Ecosystem







Definition


An ecosystem is a community of living organisms (plants, animals, and microorganisms) interacting with their physical environment (soil, water, air) in a specific area.











Biotic components


The living organisms in an ecosystem are called biotic components. They can include: Plants, animals, fungi, and microorganisms.





Living organisms interact with each other and their environment in various ways, such as through food chains, symbiotic relationships, and competition for resources.








Abiotic components


The non-living elements in an ecosystem are called abiotic components. They include: Soil, water, air, sunlight, and climate. These components provide the necessary conditions for living organisms to thrive and interact with each other.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Ecosystem






Ecosystems can be small (like a pond) or large (like a forest).








Small ecosystem: Pond ecosystem consists of fresh water system, lotus, algae, lilly, birds, frogs, toads, etc.



A pond ecosystem is a freshwater ecosystem on which different living organisms depend for their survival and nutritional needs. Ponds, due to their light penetration, are capable of supporting a diverse range of water plants.




Big ecosystem: Forest ecosystem

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Ecosystem






An ecosystem can be natural (like a rainforest) or artificial (like a city park).








A rainforest is an area of tall trees that receives a high amount of rainfall 1

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Ecosystem






Ecosystems are dynamic and can change over time due to natural processes, disturbances, or human activities. Ecosystems are interconnected, meaning that changes in one ecosystem can affect other ecosystems.








Reintroduction of Gray wolves into Yellowstone National Park in 19951



Gray wolves were reintroduced into Yellowstone National Park in 1995, resulting in a trophic cascade through the entire ecosystem. This example offers a well-documented case of how the reintroduction of a single species can trigger a chain reaction of ecological changes, demonstrating the interconnected and dynamic nature of ecosystems.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Ecosystem






Note


Ecosystems are characterized by their structure (the physical components) and function (the processes that occur within them).





Structure

Biotic components:

Producers: Algae, aquatic plants
Consumers: Insects, fish, frogs
Decomposers: Bacteria, fungi

Abiotic components:

Water, sunlight, dissolved oxygen, nutrients, temperature



Functions

Photosynthesis by algae and aquatic plants
Nutrient cycling, as decomposers break down dead organisms and release nutrients back into the water
Energy flow, from sunlight to producers, and through various levels of consumers (e.g., fish eating insects)
Oxygen production and consumption, through photosynthesis and respiration

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Ecosystem







Tansely’s Ecosystem


The British botanist-ecologist Arthur Tansely (1935) introduced the term “ecosystem”. He emphasis on combining both the organism and their environment to describe the complex interactions between living organisms and their physical environment.









Arthur Tansely




Tansely’s idea of the ecosystem was centered on the organism, species or community rather than geographic or landscape entities
In his approach every organism defines its own ecosystem. In this way, there are nearly infinite numbers of ecosystems. And it is difficult to study such systems.
On the other hand, Rowe(1961), Troll (1968), view ecosystem centered on geographic or landscape unit. Organisms are important components oof landscape ecosystem. In this waay, when we study landscape ecosystem, it is implied that organisms, species, and communities are part of such system.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Ecology









Definition


Ecology is the scientific study of “ecosystems” and their interacting biotic and abiotic components, that is, the interactions between living organisms and their environment, including the relationships among organisms and their physical surroundings.





In ecology, the terms organism, species, population, and community represent hierarchical levels of biological organization, each reflecting a different scale of interaction within the natural world.





Organism, species, population, community

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Organism







Definition


An organism is an individual living entity that carries out all basic life functions, such as metabolism, reproduction, growth, and response to stimuli.






Characteristics:

All organisms are made up of one (unicellular) or more cells (multicellular).
They can carry out chemical reactions to obtain energy and nutrients from their environment.
They can grow and develop over time, following specific patterns and stages.
They can reproduce to create new individuals, either sexually or asexually.
They can respond to changes in their environment, such as light and temperature.

Examples:

A single tree, such as a red maple, is an organism.
A deer, a bird, or a mushroom is also an organism.
Unicelluar : A bacterium

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Species







Definition


A species is a group of organisms that are genetically similar and are capable of interbreeding under natural conditions to produce fertile offspring.






Examples of species include:

Red maple (Acer rubrum): A common tree species found in North America, known for its vibrant red leaves in the fall.
White oak (Quercus alba) 白樫の木 (Shirakashi no ki): A large deciduous tree species native to eastern and central North America, valued for its strong wood and acorns.
Red oak (Quercus rubra) 赤い樫の木 (Akai kashi no ki or Akagashi): A fast-growing tree species native to North America, known for its distinctive red leaves in the fall and valuable timber.
There are more than 500 species of oak trees across the world source.





White oak tree

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Population







Definition


A population is a group of individuals of the same species that live in a specific area and interact with each other. For example, all the white oak trees in a forest make up a population.













White oak tree population







Red oak tree population

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Community







Definition


A community is a group of different populations of organisms that live together in a specific area and interact with each other. For example, a forest community may include red maple trees, oak trees, deer, squirrels, and various fungi and microorganisms.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Forest







Definition


A forest is a three-dimensional ecological system mainly dominated by trees, woody vegetation, and herbaceous plants that exist in dynamic interaction with the air-earth matrix of the landscape. It is a complex ecosystem characterized by a layered structure of functional parts.













Forest ecosystem







Layered structure of a forest ecosystem

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Forest Ecosystem







Definition


A forest ecosystem is a complex network of living organisms (plants, animals, fungi, and microorganisms) and their physical environment (soil, water, air) that interact with each other in a specific forested area. Forest ecosystems can vary widely in terms of species composition, structure, and function.













Layered structure of a forest ecosystem







Vertical Layers of forest






Our definition of forest ecosystem emphasis its structurally layered and volumetric nature. According to this definition, we should emphasize the importance of geography and physiography within a regional climatic setting to understand the vegetation type, ecosystem structure and function. The forest ecosystem is spatial in nature and is not just the extension of the biotic community.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Components of Forest-Ecosystem

The main components of a forest ecosystem include biotic and abiotic components.







Biotic components: living organisms such as trees, shrubs, animals, fungi, and microorganisms.












Tree







Shrubs







Animals







Fungi







Bacteria

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Components of Forest-Ecosystem

Abiotic components: non-living elements such as soil, water, air, climate, and fire.










Soil







Water







Air (Kaze no mori)







Climate







Fire











Energy flow: the transfer of energy through the ecosystem, primarily from the sun to plants (producers) and then to consumers (herbivores and carnivores).

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Emergent Layer



Emergent layer: the highest layer, consisting of a few tall trees that rise above the canopy.
Exposed to full sunlight, high winds, and temperature fluctuations.
Trees have thick trunks, buttressed roots, and small, waxy leaves to reduce water loss.
These trees play a role in modulating the forest’s microclimate and act as habitats for species that require direct sunlight or high nesting sites.





Layers of a forest ecosystem

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Canopy Layer



The uppermost continuous layer formed by the crowns of the majority of mature trees.
This is the primary layer of the forest where the majority of photosynthesis occurs.
It has dense, interlocking tree crowns.
Regulates light penetration to lower layers.
Serves as a shield from heavy rainfall and direct sunlight.





Layers of a forest ecosystem

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Understory Layer



Beneath the canopy and above the forest floor.
Composed of smaller trees, shrubs, and young saplings.
Plants here often have large leaves to capture scarce light.
Insects, snakes, small mammals, amphibians, and shade-tolerant plants.
Serves as a nursery for juvenile trees and provides habitat for a range of fauna adapted to low-light conditions.





Layers of a forest ecosystem

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Forest Floor Layer



Location: The bottom layer of vegetation, lying directly above the soil.
Description: Receives less than 2% of sunlight and is dominated by decaying organic matter.
Characteristics:

Dark, humid, and nutrient-rich.
Rapid decomposition due to warm and moist conditions.

Examples of Life:

Fungi, bacteria, decomposers, insects, and ground-dwelling animals like tapirs or wild boars.

Ecological Role: Critical for nutrient cycling, decomposition, and seed germination.





Layers of a forest ecosystem

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Soil Layer



Soil is the foundation of the forest ecosystem, providing nutrients and support for plant growth.
Location: Beneath the forest floor.
Description: Consists of organic, inorganic materials (minerals), water and air.
Characteristics:

Contains roots of plants, microorganisms, minerals, and decaying matter.
Influences water retention, nutrient availability, and root penetration.

Ecological Role: Serves as the foundation of plant life, supporting root systems and microbial ecosystems essential for forest health.





Layers of a forest ecosystem

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Water Components

Water is essential for all living organisms including plants, .
Location: Water is found in various forms within the forest ecosystem, including rivers, streams, and groundwater
Description: May occur at or below the surface depending on topography and hydrology.
Characteristics:

Supports aquatic and semi-aquatic species.
Interacts with soil and vegetation layers through moisture transfer.

Ecological Role: Maintains humidity, supports biodiversity, and regulates nutrient transport.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
section: Other components (layers) of a forest ecosystem
text:
Other components (layers) of a forest ecosystem

Climate: the long-term weather patterns in a region, including temperature, precipitation, and humidity. Climate influences the types of plants and animals that can thrive in a forest ecosystem.
Microclimates: small-scale variations in climate within the forest, such as shaded areas, moist spots, or sunny clearings. These microclimates can support different plant and animal species.
Biodiversity: the variety of species present in a forest ecosystem, including plants, animals, fungi, and microorganisms. High biodiversity contributes to ecosystem stability and resilience.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Keypoints about the forest ecosystem

Our definition of forest ecosystem emphasizes its structurally layered and volumetric nature.
According to this definition, we should emphasize the importance of geography and physiography within a regional climatic setting to understand the vegetation type, ecosystem structure, and function.
The forest ecosystem is spatial in nature; they have both the horizontal and vertical structures.
The forests are not just the extension of the biotic community.








Rowe (1989, p.229)


Organisms do not stand on their own: they evolve and exist in the context of ecological systems that confer those properties called life. The panda is part of the mountain bamboo-forest ecosystem and can only be preserved as such. The polar bear is a vital part of the Artic marine ecosystem and will not survive without it. Ducks are creatures born of marshes. Biology without its ecological context is dead.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Major types of forests
Forests are broadly categorized into different types depending on climatic conditions, latitude, and dominant vegetation. The three primary types are









Tropical forests







Temperate







Boreal forests

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Tropical forests

Location: Near the equator, primarily in regions of Central and South America, Central Africa, Southeast Asia, and Oceania. 10°N to 10°S latitude.
Climate: Hot and humid throughout the year with high rainfall.






Distribution of Tropical Rainforests (source: UN FRA2000 report)




They are a subset of the tropical forest biome that occurs roughly within the 28° latitudes (between the Tropic of Cancer, 23°N, and Tropic of Capricorn, 23°S )
Tropical rainforests ecosystems are distinguished by their consistent, high temperatures, exceeding 18 °C monthly, and substantial annual rainfall.
Vegetation: Dense, multi-layered with broadleaf evergreen trees.
Biodiversity: Highest species richness of all forest types, including numerous endemic species.
Ecological Importance: Crucial for global carbon sequestration, climate regulation, and genetic resources.
Structure: Emergent layer, canopy layer, understory layer, and forest floor layer. Soil is nutrient-poor and acidic due to rapid decomposition and leaching.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Temperate forests

Location: Mid-latitudes of North America, Europe, East Asia, and parts of the Southern Hemisphere. These forests cover both hemispheres at latitudes ranging from 25 to 50 degrees. These forests are found between the tropical and boreal regions.
Climate: The climate of a temperate forest is highly variable depending on the location of the forest. Moderate temperatures with distinct seasons, including cold winters and warm summers. Rainfall is well-distributed.






Distribution of temperate forests(source: UN FRA2000 report)




Vegetation:

Deciduous forests: Trees shed leaves in autumn (e.g., oak, maple).
Evergreen forests: Include conifers like pine and fir.

Biodiversity: Moderate; includes a mix of herbivores, carnivores, and migratory birds.
Ecological Importance: Support important watersheds and timber production.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Deciduous temperate forests

Deciduous temperate forests: Trees shed leaves in autumn (e.g., oak, maple).
They are found in Europe, East Asia, North America, and in some parts of South America.
Deciduous forests are composed mainly of broadleaf trees.

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Coniferous temperate forests

Coniferous forests are composed of needle-leaved evergreen trees, such as pine or fir.
Evergreen forests are typically found in regions with moderate climates.
They often have an advantage over broadleaf trees in harsher environments. Their leaves are typically hardier and longer lived but require more energy to grow.






Western Himalayan subalpine conifer forests






Leaves of coniferous tree

title: Sustainable Forest Environment (SFE)
text:
Boreal forests

Boreal forests, also known as taiga, are found in the northern regions (high latitudes) of North America, Europe, and Asia.
Climate: Long, cold winters and short, mild summers; relatively low precipitation.
Dominated by coniferous trees such as spruce, pine, and fir.
Lower species diversity; adapted to cold environments.

title: Questions asked in Lecture 3
text:
Consider the following chemical reaction:
\[
A + B \rightarrow C + D
\]
where \(A\) and \(B\) are reactants, and \(C\) and \(D\) are products.



Exothermic reaction: A chemical reaction that releases energy, usually in the form of heat. The products have lower energy than the reactants.
Endothermic reaction: A chemical reaction that absorbs energy from its surroundings. The products have higher energy than the reactants.

Why energy is released or absorbed in a chemical reaction?
In any chemical reaction, some bonds are broken and new bonds are formed. Energy is required to break the bonds which we will call as bond dissociation energy. Also, energy is released when new bonds are formed, which will be referred to as the bond formation energy.

A reaction is exotermic if the bond formation energy is greater than the bond dissociation energy.
A reaction is endothermic if the bond dissociation energy is greater than the bond formation energy.




In a chemical reaction the electrons cannot be created or destroyed, but they can be transferred from one atom to another. So the flow of electrons can only occur from a source connected to a sink. So what it means is that if in a chemical reaction electrons are flowing then someone should provide the electrons and someone should accept the electrons.
A redox reaction can be defined as a chemical reaction in which electrons are transferred between two reactants participating in it.
I have updated the lecture notes to improve the description of redox reactions in the context of forest ecology. Please refer to the updated notes for a more detailed explanation.





Photons are discrete packets of light energy. Visible light, X-rays, ultraviolet, infrared, microwaves, and radio waves all consist of photons differing in energy (frequency).
A photon’s energy is proportional to the frequency of the electromagnetic wave:

\[
E = h \nu
\]
where \(E\) is the energy of the photon, \(h\) is Planck’s constant (\(6.626 \times 10^{-34} \text{J s}\)), and \(\nu\) is the frequency of the electromagnetic wave.






wave-particle duality



During the 19th and early 20th centuries, light was found to behave as a wave then later was discovered to have a particle-like behavior, whereas electrons behaved like particles in early experiments then were later discovered to have wave-like behavior. The concept of duality arose to name these seeming contradictions.

Color perception



Light is a form of electromagnetic wave. It contains several frequencies (or wavelengths). We often call it spectrum. The visible spectrum contains wavelength from 380 to 780 nano meters. The red color has the biggest wavelength in the visible spectrum.


Every object smaller or bigger absorbs and reflects light. What it means is that the object absorbs certain wavelengths and reflects certain wavelength. The wavelength that object absorbs never reaches to our eyes, but the reflected wave lengths are received by our eyes. Therefore, we see the color corresponding to the wavelengths that have been reflected from the object.
